Author:

Name: Yusuke Endoh
Location: JP

To build:

make

To use:

./prog

Try:

./try.sh

What happens if you do

./prog prog.c

?

Judges’ remarks:

Clever use of the C99 complex data type. The spoiler directory contains clues as to how some winning authors create / edit programs into ASCII shapes.

With the source from the spoiler directory could you make the code render for a larger terminal window? How about adding more glyphs?

Author’s remarks:

No! Try not. Do, or do not. There is no try.

cc -std=c99 prog.c
./a.out
./a.out hello.txt
./a.out yoda.txt
./a.out bear.txt

See spoiler.zip for the source code. The 16th most common password on the Internet in 2017 (according to Splash Data) the password is.

Inventory for 2020/endoh2

Primary files

  • index.html - winner home page
  • prog.c - winning source
  • Makefile - winner Makefile
  • prog.orig.c - original source
  • bear.txt - sample input
  • hello.txt - sample input
  • try.sh - how to run
  • yoda.txt - sample input
  • spoiler/code.c - SPOILER WARNING - main logic for the program
  • spoiler/gen.rb - SPOILER WARNING - compose items and prog.c
  • spoiler/glyphs.txt - SPOILER WARNING - font data
  • spoiler/prog.c - SPOILER WARNING - generated source
  • spoiler/spoiler.md - SPOILER WARNING - about the spoiler
  • spoiler/tmpl.txt - SPOILER WARNING - template for the program
  • 2020_endoh2.tar.bz2 - download winning source

Secondary files

  • .gitignore - list of files that should not be committed under git
  • .path - directory path from top directory
  • .winner.json - description of winner in JSON
  • README.md - markdown source for index.html

Coda

Nu HTML check this web page
